title: 107_hr110
content: The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows small farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit for charitable conservation contributions of land. This Act is cited as the SEC. 30B Private Land Conservation. The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" provides a tax credit of 10% for eligible farmers and ranchers for qualified conservation contributions. The credit is limited to $360,000 per year, with a 15-year carryover provision. The tax credit under the "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" is limited to $360,000 per year, with a 15-year carryover provision. Joint returns allocate the credit equally between spouses for future years. Controlled group of corporations are subject to aggregation rules for the credit. The tax credit under the "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" is limited to $360,000 per year, with a 15-year carryover provision. Joint returns allocate the credit equally between spouses for future years. Controlled group of corporations and persons under common control are treated as 1 taxpayer for the credit limitation. The tax credit allowed under the "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" is limited based on the amount of tax for the taxable year. An eligible farmer or rancher is defined as an individual or C corporation with a majority of gross income from farming. The term 'eligible farmer or rancher' is defined as an individual or C corporation with at least 60% of gross income from farming, not publicly traded, with farming assets not exceeding $20,000,000. Taxpayers must elect for the tax credit to apply for the taxable year. The tax credit applies to eligible farmers or ranchers with farming assets under $20,000,000. Taxpayers must elect for the credit to apply for the taxable year, and once chosen, it is irrevocable. No deduction under section 170 is allowed for a qualified conservation contribution if the taxpayer elects the credit for a 15-taxable-year period. The tax credit applies to eligible farmers or ranchers with farming assets under $20,000,000. Taxpayers must elect for the credit to apply for the taxable year, and once chosen, it is irrevocable. No deduction under section 170 is allowed for a qualified conservation contribution if the taxpayer elects the credit for a 15-taxable-year period. Excess credit can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year. Sec. 30B. Private land conservation. The amendments apply to donations of qualified conservation contributions made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Increase in charitable contribution limit for farmers and ranchers in corporate form. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code allow qualified farmers and ranchers to be treated as individuals for conservation contributions. The changes apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 expands the estate tax exclusion for land under qualified conservation easements. The amendment applies to estates of decedents dying after the enactment of the Act.
